questions.question: One of the world's most visited UNESCO sites, where a statue once held a torch to welcome immigrants near the end of the 19th century, is now found on an island in North America. What is this iconic location?
questions.context: Gifted by France in 1886, this colossal neoclassical statue symbolizes freedom and democracy.

questions.question: Identify the modern architectural marvel in the Middle East, known for its luxury and status, where a sail-shaped hotel dominates the skyline and sits on an artificial island.
questions.context: Completed in 1999, this luxurious hotel is often referred to as the world's only '7-star hotel' due to its lavish amenities.

questions.question: Locate the UNESCO site in East Asia that is revered for its ancient temple complex, built as a Hindu monument in the early 12th century by a famous king and now forms the symbol of its nation.
questions.context: Constructed by King Suryavarman II, Angkor Wat is the largest religious monument in the world, initially dedicated to Vishnu.

questions.question: This European dark tourism site, built in the late 19th century, is infamously known for housing the inmate who sparked the First World War. It is still visited by many history enthusiasts. What is this place?
questions.context: Though primarily known as a Federal prison, its infamous inmates and daring escape attempts fuel its allure in popular culture.

questions.question: Visit the ancient ruins in the Middle East, where a famous tomb built in the 1st century BC showcases intricate rock-cut architecture and was part of a vital trade route. Name this archaeological wonder.
questions.context: Also known as the Rose City due to the color of the stone, Petra was once a thriving capital of the Nabataean empire before falling to the Romans.
